												I'm sure you've already read this in other reviews, but just in case: The only reason there are so many negative reviews is because there were some issues at launch. And people found that a good enough reason to riot. After playing for only about half an hour, I can already see where this game is most likely going. I can see a bit of meta forming, and each of the dragons clearly has their own playstyle and purpose. I can't say for sure if this game is going to get better or worse over time - but as is, it's worth an hour or so of your time. It's incredibly easy to pick up (you don't even need to know what any of the keys do the first time you jump into a match. You'll be fine.)  I like how your starting dragon is a bit of a heavyweight. Not the bulkiest of the bunch, I assure you, but they have enough HP so that you'll survive a few of the hits you're no doubt going to be taking while you improve. They're enough of a middle-ground so that you can jump into any of the other dragons with enough basic experience under your belt to know what you're doing. Though I have only played a few games, I'm noticing that I only see about one of a type of dragon per team, which is nice. It's a good indicator that there isn't a clearly broken dragon to play as. Yet. The airplay is a little frustrating at times and momentum doesn't seem to work exactly as it should (I would love to see an update where it's possible to build up a lot of speed and then ram right into them. With recoil, of course. Right now, the dragons don't really feel like they have weight to them.) but it's a solid starting point. That seems to be my all-around opinion on this game, actually. It's hit the ground running with a solid start in it's development and I'd love to see where the devs take the game from here. It's definately possible for this to fall flat, but who really knows? Best of luck to you, devs.

												So yeah, neat concept, nice that it's free to play but still a total waste of time.  :/As promises, I played the game again after this latest update. The developers did fix the bugs I experienced prior. However, it appears that the ship of opportunity has sailed for the developers.To really kick this review into gear, let me start by saying this game that only offers PvP with no form of NPC or combative AI is a huge mistake. This game is international based, yet the entire 30+ minutes I flew in circles and I never ran across a single player on any map. This game is a barren wasteland of nothingness. Literally a total waste of time.Next, this game is loaded with microtransactions. Now I get it, dev's have a right to earn funds from their product, I agree with the idea but they're doing it horribly wrong. For starters, this game offers NOTHING different, unique, or new in comparison to other PvP competitors. Sure, you can argue the basis of content that your fighting on dragon back but, there needs to actually "be" another player to fight. There is no one most of the time. So that argument is not only invalid but impractical. The prices for their products are incredibly high and there is no incentive to even contribute to this community of developers. Every single action has been a step on the wrong foot in the wrong direction by the dev's and this path may not be capable of recovering from.Lastly, the final nail in the coffin of this review. You see, this is solely a PvP game. When a PvP game doesn't work, people will go to the thousands of other options out there. If a solely PvP game is gonna last, it needs to be good from the start or have some super stubborn Dev's who are willing to take a net loss early on. So, lets compare this game to another highly celebrated PvP game:* Team Fortress 2 for the longest time was a pretty much just a PvP based game before the release of Man vs Machine. the game offered loads of different maps and combat strategies with a range of diversity FROM THE START. All characters and maps were unlocked from the very beginning.By locking out all of the dragons and map types for a game and group of developers that have NO reputation what so ever the developers have completely locked out any possible redeming features. I'd try to get my profile to level 3 to try out other maps, but no one plays. If I can't play against anyone, I can't level. So definitely no redemption here.As I said, neat concept and there are a load of opportunities with this idea, but at the end of the day this product was so buggy and incomplete with sooooo little content it's turned out to be a total waste of effort and time. I see there are a lot of people who wrote positive reviews, but when you take the time to read the reviews there is nothing sufficient stating why the game is good. People by nature like to positively rate something if has an idea they like associate with the material. In this case, dragons, flying, pvp, laser guns. All popular topics fused into one unique, though incomplete concept. Thing is though, pretty much the majority of all of these positive reviews have less than an hour of play and I doubt most people take time to spend initial gameplay to analyze and study the game before dedicating time to playing.What this says is the idea has merit, people "want" something like this, but Dev's, you gotta fix your micro transations and a LOT more content and fast.Best of luck, over and out.--------------------------------------------------Previous Bugs in Forementioned Post:* Players would get permanently stuck in blue phantom form during rez or spawning of character.* When timer for mission runs out "with" players the mission timer gets stuck at 00:01 and never ends, forcing you to abort manually and loose all progress.* When timer for missin runs out "without" players and you actually wait for timer to run out, you get a draw being the only player who stuck out all 7 minutes. No reward for dedication.* When you get reward crates, you ONLY get one skin, and it's the same one every time. Forgot the name, but it's the blue one for starter dragon. I opened 7 crates, same thing every time no matter what container I picked.

When you run into the higher levels, the level really doesn't mean anything other then gameplay time and how many matches that person has been in. Before reaching the status I am at now in game, I had a rough ride in the beginning worse then most starting out now. There was no tutorial and the game only had TDM and DM. I had to learn on the fly and my k/d was actually only a 0.03 from the time I was a lvl 1 to a lvl 8. I had help from players that are sadly no longer around and did pay it forward in helping other new players learn up until the tutorial was released. In short, yes the beginning levels are tough but the more you practice and get the hang of the mechanics, the better you do get in game.Certain dragons do well with specific builds. That I will admit to in this game. Wrong or bad building mechanic does make a kill per death worse for a player pending on the dragon. When you start getting use to the game, you fall into one of five nitches in game. Aggressor, Support, Marksman, Tansverse or Ambusher are the main nitches in game. The dragon used the most is what helps place a player into that specific nitch when in game.The maps right now are very detailed but don't trying swimming as you'll drown the poor dragon. Sadly dragons cannot swim in this game or the water is an acid. Not sure which it is though.Pros: Great multiplayer, different dragon and non dragon type of creatures, very well balanced between the dragon types, Huge maps, A nice mix of both day and night, Nicely detailed with the mapsCons: Still buggy, a few players still "teleport" (lag in and out) somehow across the map making it difficult to shoot at them. Summary:I've been playing this game for awhile and I personally enjoy it. Most of the bugs are UI/lobby related and the core game-play works well enough for a free game. Sure, the recent update added micro-transactions, but it's VERY far from a pay to win game. After having it be 100% free for awhile, I didn't mind pitching in $8 for a new dragon to support the devs.My advice: Play this game with minimum expectations and just play it for awhile. Sure you'll die a lot at first, but it becomes enjoyable once you eventually learn how to move and shoot. Overall I give this a 6.5/10. It's a fun game, just that the bugs need to be worked out before I'd give it an 8-9/10.Pros:- Dragons with FRICKIN' LAZURRS strapped to their back!- Decently balanced game-play. Each dragon class is the same for everyone, each weapon type damage the same as everyone. Doesn't matter what level you are. If you screw up, you die just as easily as everyone else. Although that's not to say there isn't room for improvement.- "Paid dragons" are obtainable with normal game-play, and don't give an large, unfair, advantage. I bought one of the dragons and it's stats barely differ from it's default counterpart. Mostly cosmetic changes with a new ability, but still relies mainly on player skill. Advantage is marginal at best.- Game-play is quick, fun, and straight-forward for the most part. This is the kind of game you play if you want a break and want to shoot down some dragons.Neutral:- Graphics are okay, but sub-par. Sound design is rather simple. There's definitely room for improvement.- Learning curve ranges from moderate to hard. This is in-part due to being in the same room as experienced players. You will die a lot before you get a feel for how to move and shoot in this game. Then again, that's the same for most games.Cons:- Bugs. Bugs everywhere. Ranges from spawning outside the insta-death fence, to crashing when trying to load certain maps, to errors when unlocking dragons. The UI feels really clunky. Features like room/lobby info are missing, there's no chat history, and dragon selection in-game sometimes glitches. Just to name a few.- No option to chose a room. Can't even know how many people are in a specific game mode without entering it to check. It's just "choose a game mode and hope for the best."- No team auto-balance. It just places people in each team in order of when they first joined the room. This sometimes leads to all the high-level players being on one team, and low-levels on the other.- Not a whole bunch of people play. Depending on what time you're on, all the game modes can be empty. Granted, people do still play and there are occasionally have full rooms.

												All in all a good Aerial Combat game.This originally showed up in my discovery queue, and after reading the page i immediately downloaded it to try.GAME MECHANICS & COMBAT:This is an Aerial Combat game set up a little like COD with Deathmatch/TeamDeathmatch and other objective based sessions. You can play as 8 different starting dragons as well as several hybrid forms unlocked later.In these sessions you shoot from your dragons back with energy guns of sorts.However, the issue i found with the guns are the shot sights.they turn when your dragon does with some delays depending on the speed of your chosen dragon, which is fine, but even the fast dragons take really long to re-center their sights.... The really high mobility and speed dragons even have this issue, meaning close quarters combat can get very hard...MAPS:This brings me to the maps. There are not many maps, all of them have lots of diversity, even with day/night variants for some. Though, many of the maps are not very big for a flight game, excluding say the "Islands" map.This is where the dragon sights re-center time is an issue, since the maps are small you will be turning alot, meaning a lot of time you can't really attack...More maps would be cool, as well as bigger ones since fighting in the same few over and over can get tiresome...MATCHES VS SYSTEM:The match system is interesting. However there is no balancer to the teams, meaning that you could be put into a session that currently has 1V5 players.Also there is a way to link up with your friends to do matches together, like parties or groups, which is a nice addition.MODES:As of now there is only the battle modes, being: Deathmatch/TeamDeathmatch & a sort of capture the flag session style where the "flags" are your enemy team's "souls".Since this is an Aerial combat game it would be cool if they added a freeroam mode, where you could chose a map to fly in and just explore, or play with your friends in.A freeroam would also be nice since there ARE such few modes to chose from.Of course if a freeroam mode was added, there would need to be activities to do. Maybe add races for players to fly through, or hidden object challenges?This could add more variety to the game and attract more players.LEVEL & MATCHING:Now, this game is an MMO. This also means there is a levels system.You get EXP from matches which go to your level.However, it seems the only reason for your level is to lock some modes until a higher level or to show other players your experience level in the game. It doesn't even do anything for the matching system, since in some cases I myself have been placed on a team of 3 level 3-8's VS 5 level 38-62's....This would be better if it had more use, but it is there...BUGS & LAG:The game doesn't have many lag issues, usually loading quite fast.I have incountered a bug in the last little while where the daily crates have first started giving 1 with each login regardless of the day and then stopped appearing all together..The bug i mentioned previously in this review however has been fixed.All that aside, as a player i would probably give this game a 7/10 in its current state.

Posted: April 27, 2016
												For a free, early access game this is looking pretty good so far. I enjoy flying around and defeating other dragons with the use of missiles and plasma cannons. I even went through a phase of playing this game often and in doing so, I noticed I was playing with the same players over and over. Even the leaderboards contain mostly players I have seen and played with before. After playing against some of the same people a few times, it can actually feel like two players have something against each other and begin trying to kill each other more than the other players. As with many games, you can hurt players on your team which can lead to you being betrayed (this normally only happens when there are no enemies and your team seems to get bored easily) or accidentally hit. Of course this problem lies within player attitude and not the game itself. I can say though, that the lack of enemies (or teammates for that matter) seems to be down to the game seemingly having no team balancing which results in a lot of unfair matches.The flight feels quite nice and fluid for the most part but it can be hard to determine the scale and distance of certain objects in the environment. So when you are flying around and you notice you're coming quite close to something large, you usually try to turn sharply or pull up which is difficult sometimes as the dragon seems to want to almost drift and keep moving forward as opposed to just sharply and swiftly pulling up. Most of the time you end up crashing into said object which makes you more vulnerable to attack. The turret/weapon system is great. It features a number of weapons and items to help you in battle such as plasma turrets (default weapon/fire type), missiles and a special attack that is performed with the R key if I can remember correctly. Most of the special attacks are short range and have what seems to be a spherical radius. In my opinion, the Ogre's (big green, tank-like dragon) special attack is overpowered, since he can stun you and keep you in one spot then use his vast amount of health and firepower to quickly dispose of you.Anyway, my next point about the turret and weapons system is that the crosshair seems to take a very long time to catch up with where your dragon is looking which can be annoying when you have a clear shot ready but your crosshair is nowhere to be seen. Earlier I mentioned items. These items include stamina refill, weapon cooldown, mines (that float in the air) and a smoke screen (I may have missed something from the list). These also have a cooldown period but can give you an edge in battle and instantly regenerate upon respawning after death. The mines and smoke screen can be good items to use and can make a great combo as you can drop a mine if you're being followed, then drop the smoke screen which will blind your enemy and lead them to fly into the mine. The smoke screen can also hide you when you're on low health and allow you to escape. Your dragon can be given a speed boost (shift key) which takes stamina rather quickly but (if you have it equipped) you can use your stamina refill to give your dragon a second boost.I did notice that the models and sounds seem to be based off other games/movies... The Inara - Ikran (Avatar) (Similar sounds too)The Fury - Toothless (HTTYD/2) (Also similar sounds)The Vampire (mainly it's head) reminds me of creatures from the old game Altered Beast but may just be a coincidence.Tiamat is given the same name as the bat queen from Darksiders (perhaps this dragon was given this name instead of the vampire since it would have looked too close to Tiamat). Again, perhaps it's just coincidence or I'm just looking into it too much.This game is very team based with nice graphics and a great idea behind it. It's a great game for passing the time and having fun and can actually be quite competitive. When you have balanced teams, it can be very enjoyable. If you enjoy team based, dragon flying, weapon firing action then this game is for you. I recommend trying this game and seeing what you think. I may have written a bunch of bad points (which I seem to find it hard not to with most things) but I do really like this game.I apologise for this painfully long (not as painful as my overuse of certain words) review but thank you for reading - if you didn't die of old age before getting to the end... This is my first review.

Essentially you earn "DNA" points as you rank up, but all you do with it is unlock dragons... which there aren't very many of at the moment. I imagine in the future it will be used to unlock weapons, upgrade dragon specific abilities and such. TL;DR: Time of Dragons is, overall, a good game for free. Suffers from a lack of players.Pros:+ free game without microtransactions+ dragons with freakin' laser beams+ little bugs/issues that I've come across (addressed in cons section)+ decent Halo-esque 3D textures for a small indie game+ games don't snowball (unless your "team" leaves you)+ small game+ high framerateNeutrals:/ little player count; I've typically only ever seen one lobby./ achievements (I love me some achivements)/ OS X support (although not many people game on macs, it works very well on my rMBP)Cons:- Kill assist system a little weird/buggy; I'll whittle a player down and someone else will sweep in for the KS (which isn't so much the game's fault as thhe player's) but then I don't receive credit half of the time.- Not a whole lot to do due to low player count- Cannot pass tutorial level due to not being able to shoot when prompted despite repeatedly clicking the left mouse button. Works well otherwise.Points of interest:{ Controls take a bit of getting used to, but fun and easy to handle when you get the hang of it. Took me a bit to get turning down.{ Higher level players get only a bigger number next to their name and access to having more, but not particularly better, dragons, giving more to players with more skill rather than a higher level.{ Right now, it's best playing with a friend so at the very least just to have someone to play against. (Can be seen as a pro if you like private lobbies, or as a con because you can't lobby hop if you don't particularly like the players in a certain game.)Overall an entertaining game for free. Would recommend if you want to kill a few hours. Needs more players to play with/against, which you can help with by getting the game!8/10~Pie(Edit: Formatting + TL;DR)

												This is a game with major potential. Seeing how the devs are still working on it as people are reporting bugs and other things, there's a high chance they're going to exploit that potential.For now, let's talk about the game in its current state. The graphics are good for now. My PC is pretty low-end but I can still run on the highest settings on the opening screen without dropping frames (however, there is an in-game setting for post effects that makes the game look ugly AND drops your frames immensely, so this setting should be removed or fixed pronto, but just turn it off in the in-game settings for now if you're having problems). Actual gameplay is very, very...FUN.I feel like I could play this game for hours on end without getting bored of it. Time will tell if that feeling will continue, but as of right now, everythings running a smooth course. Graphics, audio, animation... none of that really completely matters if the gameplay isn't fun. And this game's gameplay is straight up, pure, magical fun. I mean the concept itself sounds fun, just think about it! Fire-breathing dragons with missiles and lasers mounted to them? That's awesome! And the fact that it is executed so well in this game makes it all feel incredible.The only bad things in this game are the bugs and some of the audio. Let's start with that audio. The music in this game is pretty darn cool, but the sound effects are plainly sub-par. They need to be remastered in order for me to feel fully submerged into the game, because otherwise, it feels like there's no reality to this game when those fuzzy, low-qual dragon roars play. Now, the bugs are mostly with the HUD. Sometimes when you're in the options menu, you can't click the accept button. That's one example. There are also collision bugs regarding dragons running into walls even when they haven't even touched the walls. Other things, like certain flight animations, need to be polished and more rounded. But perhaps those animations help with the game's charm. Honestly, I really don't care about charm.All that matters is that you should give this game a shot. It's got class, fun, and dragons with GUNS on them for crying out loud. It deserves a chance, so try it out, at least for a half hour.TL;DR:This game has a couple bugs but it's incredibly fun, so try it!

												I'd have to say that I love this game. I learned the controls in just a few matches. They are simple enough for anyone to use, but have enough flexibility and complexity to pull of maneuvers you'd think came from a jet combat simulator. The health and damage system is adequate, being shot at is a real risk, unlike a lot of other first or third person shooters, where you'd think the character was the man of steel. Unlike other shooters, I managed to make my first kills in my very first match, which was very satisfying. A game that takes too long to offer the player some incentive to play, is hard to continue playing. Time of Dragons is not one of those games.For the most part, the game is evenly balanced (And the promise of biweekly updates means that whatever tweaks need to be made to keep it fair, can happen), the lack of "upgrades" in the usual sense making combat a test of skill over grinding. The sense of progression is present, and from the start the game offers you the opportunity to test out several of the different dragons, to see which fits your playstyle the best. There are dragons out there for a mix of niches, whether you like a heavy hitter or a swift and agile fighter. (Which appealed to me the most.)Sure, there isn't much content to this game. But do all games need content? The matches are quick, six minutes each if you join from the start, perfect for when you just want to take a break. But there's enough variation in the Team and Solo deathmatch modes and maps to offer several hours of unique play. No match feels quite the same. The matchmaking system itself could offer more, though it is relatively fair, and again, even a new player can trump the most experienced if they take a well-aimed shot.For being free-to-play, the game is astoundingly well put-together. It is the first shooter that I've been able to run at full resolution and graphics quality without losing the most precious commodity these game need, framerate. The maps are very well thought-out, with places to hide and ambush and space for an all-out dogfight. The music, unintruding and not distracting in the least (in fact, I would go as far as to say it is beautiful) is quite fitting to an aerial combat game like this,  a refreshing break from the grating "hardcore" shooter music. Sometimes when you're all alone in a match (It happens every once in a while) you'll find yourself just soaring around the map, feeling like the king of the world. Overall the game shows great promise in what is to come, and great fun in what is already there. I can see myself staying with this game for many months.

												Ok, this game...8/10   To explain such a high rating, let me just say DRAGONS with FREAKING LAZER GUNS! That puts it pretty high in my sights for a one-play kind of game. Then I kept playing. You can only have 3 dragons in the start, but you can get all of them eventually. They cost 3 each and you get a point every level. This is not a pay-to-win at all, I didn't even see an option to pay. The graphics (highest setting) are a lot better than expected and the controls have the perfect balance of complexity (for detailed shooting and movement) and simplicity (for ease of play.)   The only problem I have for this game was the lack of tons of dragons (which wasn't expected anyways), for there is only 10. All of them are different enough to be interesting to play all of them. Also, there are only 2 game modes and a third to come. Free for all and Team deathmatch. The third is some kind of point control, or defend the location, or attack the blimps, or something like that.   More game modes, dragons, and the leveling actually doing something would be the only things I think could make it better. Game modes such as Capture the flag, or a storyline, or custom enemies spawning in, stuff like that. More content to improve replayability. The Dragons are cool as they are, but there are more kinds that can be made. Speciality ones like ones that can resist certain moves, but have a crappy super move. The leveling is a bit of a touchy subject, in the sense that I realize all the dragons are on the same playing field, and leveling that changes stats would make the game unfair. I like the idea of your level unlocking game modes, or perhaps arena rooms (more and more skilled rooms.)    I really like this game, it's exactly what I wanted in my childhood (and I am sure yours too.) I am glad I found it here. Good job developers!-Azure

Posted: April 12, 2016
												Actually pretty good, for what it is. It has very low system requirements, and it runs on unity. Graphics and AestheticsGraphics are good considering its low system requirements (My broken PC can run it!), but some textures are a bit eh, and animations are lacking in "umf" especially when you fire rockets and kill opposing dragons. The plasma lasers feel as they should, though a sound for them colliding with a dragon would be cool, instead of just numbers popping up. Rockets and Plasma Balls feel kinda eh as well.  The game is very colorful, and has a wide variety of dragons, which homage some familiar tropes (Such as the tyrannosaurus-esque Tiamat dragon, and the European starter dragon), as well as homaging familiar dragons in movies (The Fury and Ogre dragons in particular look like 2 particular dragons from How To Train Your Dragon, though only vaguely).StoryLiterally nonexistant, not even little bits of flavor text for each dragon. Not important, but would be nice to see!MechanicsFlying is fun, though going up and down feels a bit slow, and the flying can be quite sluggish at times. (Good luck zipping around corners, even with a fast dragon!) The combat options are lacking, 1 machine-gun esque weapon for each dragon, an option of a Plasma Ball, Rocket, or Rail Shot for a secondary weapon, and 2 accessory slots for things like mines and things to restore your cooldowns. Each dragon also has its own unique "ultimate" ability, which is the only difference between dragons aside from their stats. Each can equip the same weapons. It feels kind of boring, honestly. More variety in weapon types would make this much more fun. The cooldown time for using your weapons feels too restrictive, and all the dragons have the same cooldowns. The actual combat, however, is fun and intuitive, which is what really matters for a game this simple. Zipping, dodging, and dogfighting another dragon can be quite fun.Misc criticismsIn TDM, theres no indicator telling what is an allied dragon or an enemy dragon. Friendly fire is on. This need to be fixed.Not enough players, but this will change with time, as its a very new game.The progression system is kind of pointless, really.Overall?Reccomended, especially for free! I advise the devs to start building some new weapons options for the dragons, and refining their movement system.

Time to LeaveOverviewI didn't play this game for very long before coming to my conclusions, and really, you don't have to play the game long at all to know what it's about. Time of Dragons was a pretty fun and clever concept, with dragons carrying turrets on their back and blazing into an all-out war with other dragon species. It seems like a rare breed. However, it's spoiled by one fatal flaw: it's multiplayer PvP only.The Positives1) Engaging, action-filled combat. It's fun to see stuff explode.2) The dragons, while kind of blocky and mushy-looking, have cool designs, and they're all unique from each other.3) The game is free to play, and there's no P2W system of any kind.The Negatives1) It was fun for five minutes, then started getting boring really fast, mostly because of your lack of options. Do you want to PvP in this way or this way? It's all the same thing: kill the other players and win. There was no variety whatsoever, and the few choices you do have aren't very interesting.2) I couldn't really get a leg-up in terms of experience since everyone who was playing seemed to be higher and better than me. Again, this made the game boring pretty quickly, because there is no skill scaling. What's the point of fighting if I can't win anything? Not fun. Moving on.3) The abilities don't seem to do anything. I've hit my special ability several times on enemies and tried like hell to get it to land on them. It doesn't seem to hurt them. Even if it did, they usually managed to kill me before I could tell. I tried the fire blast with Tiamat and vampirism thing that drains health with Vampire, and neither seemed to hurt the enemy. Maybe I just couldn't land it right, but should it really be that hard to land? Especially in a high-action environment where I don't have a lot of time to swoop in and hump the enemy before using my ability?4) Almost the entire playerbase was Russian for some reason. So I couldn't even chat with people. Even if I could, it's not like I'd have anything to say except "Hey, can you help me kill this dragon so I don't die again?" I'm sure if I banged my head on the keyboard a bunch of times, it'd have the same effect.5) There's no single-player or PvE options, so if you enter a battleground and see no other players... that's it. You have to leave and join another one and hope you have other people to play with. And if you're on at the wrong time of day, no one at all will be around. Unless they're Russians, I guess. Which is fine, if you're Russian.6) Turning is slow as hell and has gotten me killed more than once. Even when using an evasive maneuver, it was impossible to avoid an attack if the dragon was already on your♥♥♥♥♥7) It says each dragon has a "role" but they don't come into play at all. Players don't really stick together (because the teams are usually 2 or 3 people), so roles are pointless. It's pretty much what you think works best for keeping your♥♥♥♥♥alive. So pick a dragon with high health and high damage every time so you have a fighting chance.Final ThoughtsThere's nothing special about it. It's just mundane multiplayer PvP with players you can't understand. Skip this one and move on. Unless you like to be frustrated. Then be my guest.It could very well be that I played the game at "the wrong time of day" and maybe more US players join in the evening, but that still shouldn't matter. Whether you're playing in the morning of evening, you should still see more than ten players at a time.

Posted: August 20, 2016
												Time of Dragons is a really fun roguelike game about rebels (the Punks) fighting against an authoritarian government. Gameplay consists of attacking bunkers (FPS sections) to acquire gear, credits and tech, then going back to base and using the collected credits to buy new rooms & room upgrades, which will then grant your characters bonuses. When a character dies, he/she gives a permanent bonus to other characters, and when all characters die, it's game over and you're taken to the marketplace, where you can use your collected tech to buy new Punks, gear, weapons, rooms, room upgrades, room slots and character slots.As the game is currently (July 29th, 2016), version 0.2.1, the game is still lacking in content, as it'd be expected of such an early version. But even then, I still had some good hours of fun with this - 9 hours registered right now, which were needed to unlock everything currently available. If at this current, early development state I was already able to have so much fun, I can only wonder how many hours I'd put into this once the full version is out.As it'd be expected of an early version of the game, there are a few issues, but only one is worth mentioning right now, which is an issue with enemy hitbox sizes. Sometimes, the aim reticle can be right on top of an enemy, but it still shows up as white (meaning the shot will miss).However, the dev is active and listening to player feedback, taking note of all issues reported and fixing them ASAP.Definitely a game worth supporting and recommending. Even as an early access title, I still recommend it at full price.

This is very healthy small studio development at its finest. everything works, there are a pleasing amount of upgrades that i was able to earn in a half hours play session, there are some people on servers and the UI makes most stuff pretty clear. the actual dragonfighting is fun! it's slower paced than other flight or dogfighting games and theres a large variety of animations in the dragon characters which make it feel very natural and cool to flap and glide around and do popup attacks and dive in for the kill. a full server would be very awesome.I would like to see perching and hanging implemented, as you can't land anywhere - your dragon fumbles around until you can flap ungracefully back into the sky.  im thinking of the batman games style drop/snatch attacks here. also going to moan in passing aboutgeneral art direction (it all looks a bit disjointed, get a theme going on to tie it all together)level art quality (maybe you guys should stylize this thing?)lighting (black dragons get old fast)some level topography (the nightworld map with all its tunnels and overlooks is my favourite so far, some of the other levels need more height to be more of a playground for flying)but omfg dragons! reccomended!

												This game looked interesting to me, so I decided to check it out. The tutorial was fun for me, no glitches experienced. I enjoyed flying and diving into the water at that part. It gave me starry eyes. Then when I actually got into the game for battle for the first time, there was nobody else to fight, so I went to a different server. People were there, but I couldn't spawn in! My dragon was invisible, wouldn't load, and wouldn't move. I assumed it was a poorly made "Spectator mode." So, I joined another server. The round was getting ready to begin in 5 seconds. I waited patiently. As soon as the round began, my dragon was STILL invisible and couldn't move. That's when it hit me. "This isn't a Spectator Mode! It's a glitch!" Literally every time I tried to play, this "no-spawn" glitch occured. Making it very unenjoyable. Sometimes I would even get the "battle prize" at the end of the battle without even having gotten a chance to battle. How frustrating. Later on in the game, I got a crate full of 6 DNA, and decided to get a new dragon with it. Guess what? That new dragon actually worked and allowed me to spawn and play. Wow. That's a bad sign when your DEFAULT dragon that you automatically get when you first begin the game doesn't work outside of the tutorial. Imagine if I had 0 DNA. I wouldn't have been able to experience anything.Because of this game-stopping glitch, I can't really recommend this game. It's not even just the glitch though. It's also the fact that there are OTHER glitches, such as the match not ending correctly. It's also the fact that I don't like how the servers work, you can't choose which server you want to go on to. The game randomly picks one. Meaning you could spawn into a game with 0 players, or spawn into a game with 2 players, or a game with 8 players. It would be better if I could personally choose which server I want to spawn in, so I always spawn in a populated one. Also, the aiming. The aiming isn't too great. It's slow. (Dunno quite if that's because of the dragon I chose or because that's how the game is.) You can turn your dragon to face the target head on, but the targetting icon will still be trying to catch-up with your screen. So, because of that, you could be facing a target, but still shoot to your left or right, completely missing the target because the icon literally represents where your dragon will shoot, it's not just there for visual help.I'll probably keep the game just for something to play when I get a little bored, since it has a nice concept and there are still aspects about it I like, but there are too many cons for me to suggest it to anyone else.
